Address.description: Address represents an IPv4 or IPv6 IP address.

PrefixLen.description: Mask length of the IP address.

BuildCache.description: BuildCache contains information about a build cache record.

CreatedAt.description: Date and time at which the build cache was created in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

Description.description: Description of the build-step that produced the build cache.

ID.description: Unique ID of the build cache record.

InUse.description: Indicates if the build cache is in use.

LastUsedAt.description: Date and time at which the build cache was last used in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

Parent.description: ID of the parent build cache record.\n\n> **Deprecated**: This field is deprecated, and omitted if empty.

Parents.description: List of parent build cache record IDs.

Shared.description: Indicates if the build cache is shared.

Size.description: Amount of disk space used by the build cache (in bytes).

ChangeType.description:
Kind of change

Can be one of:

- `0`: Modified ("C")
- `1`: Added ("A")
- `2`: Deleted ("D")

ClusterInfo.description: ClusterInfo represents information about the swarm as is returned by the\n"/info" endpoint. Join-tokens are not included.

CreatedAt.description: Date and time at which the swarm was initialised in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

DataPathPort.description: DataPathPort specifies the data path port number for data traffic.\nAcceptable port range is 1024 to 49151.\nIf no port is set or is set to 0, the default port (4789) is used.

DefaultAddrPool.description: Default Address Pool specifies default subnet pools for global scope\nnetworks.

RootRotationInProgress.description: Whether there is currently a root CA rotation in progress for the swarm

SubnetSize.description: SubnetSize specifies the subnet size of the networks created from the\ndefault subnet pool.

UpdatedAt.description: Date and time at which the swarm was last updated in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

ClusterVolume.description: Options and information specific to, and only present on, Swarm CSI\ncluster volumes.

ID.description: The Swarm ID of this volume. Because cluster volumes are Swarm\nobjects, they have an ID, unlike non-cluster volumes. This ID can\nbe used to refer to the Volume instead of the name.

Info.description: Information about the global status of the volume.

AccessibleTopology.description: The topology this volume is actually accessible from.

CapacityBytes.description: The capacity of the volume in bytes. A value of 0 indicates that\nthe capacity is unknown.

VolumeContext.description: A map of strings to strings returned from the storage plugin when\nthe volume is created.

VolumeID.description:
The ID of the volume as returned by the CSI storage plugin. This
is distinct from the volume's ID as provided by Docker. This ID
is never used by the user when communicating with Docker to refer
to this volume. If the ID is blank, then the Volume has not been
successfully created in the plugin yet.

PublishStatus.description: The status of the volume as it pertains to its publishing and use on\nspecific nodes

NodeID.description: The ID of the Swarm node the volume is published on.

PublishContext.description: A map of strings to strings returned by the CSI controller\nplugin when a volume is published.

State.description:
The published state of the volume.
* `pending-publish` The volume should be published to this node, but the call to the controller plugin to do so has not yet been successfully completed.
* `published` The volume is published successfully to the node.
* `pending-node-unpublish` The volume should be unpublished from the node, and the manager is awaiting confirmation from the worker that it has done so.
* `pending-controller-unpublish` The volume is successfully unpublished from the node, but has not yet been successfully unpublished on the controller.

ClusterVolumeSpec.description: Cluster-specific options used to create the volume.

AccessMode.description: Defines how the volume is used by tasks.

AccessibilityRequirements.description: Requirements for the accessible topology of the volume. These\nfields are optional. For an in-depth description of what these\nfields mean, see the CSI specification.

Preferred.description: A list of topologies that the volume should attempt to be\nprovisioned in.

Requisite.description: A list of required topologies, at least one of which the\nvolume must be accessible from.

Availability.description:
The availability of the volume for use in tasks.
- `active` The volume is fully available for scheduling on the cluster
- `pause` No new workloads should use the volume, but existing workloads are not stopped.
- `drain` All workloads using this volume should be stopped and rescheduled, and no new ones should be started.

CapacityRange.description: The desired capacity that the volume should be created with. If\nempty, the plugin will decide the capacity.

LimitBytes.description: The volume must not be bigger than this. The value of 0\nindicates an unspecified maximum.

RequiredBytes.description: The volume must be at least this big. The value of 0\nindicates an unspecified minimum

MountVolume.description:
Options for using this volume as a Mount-type volume.

    Either MountVolume or BlockVolume, but not both, must be
    present.
  properties:
    FsType:
      type: "string"
      description: |
        Specifies the filesystem type for the mount volume.
        Optional.
    MountFlags:
      type: "array"
      description: |
        Flags to pass when mounting the volume. Optional.
      items:
        type: "string"
BlockVolume:
  type: "object"
  description: |
    Options for using this volume as a Block-type volume.
    Intentionally empty.

Scope.description: The set of nodes this volume can be used on at one time.\n- `single` The volume may only be scheduled to one node at a time.\n- `multi` the volume may be scheduled to any supported number of nodes at a time.

Secrets.description: Swarm Secrets that are passed to the CSI storage plugin when\noperating on this volume.

items.description: One cluster volume secret entry. Defines a key-value pair that\nis passed to the plugin.

Key.description: Key is the name of the key of the key-value pair passed to\nthe plugin.

Secret.description:
Secret is the swarm Secret object from which to read data.
This can be a Secret name or ID. The Secret data is
retrieved by swarm and used as the value of the key-value
pair passed to the plugin.

Sharing.description:
The number and way that different tasks can use this volume
at one time.
- `none` The volume may only be used by one task at a time.
- `readonly` The volume may be used by any number of tasks, but they all must mount the volume as readonly
- `onewriter` The volume may be used by any number of tasks, but only one may mount it as read/write.
- `all` The volume may have any number of readers and writers.

Group.description:
Group defines the volume group of this volume. Volumes belonging to
the same group can be referred to by group name when creating
Services.  Referring to a volume by group instructs Swarm to treat
volumes in that group interchangeably for the purpose of scheduling.
Volumes with an empty string for a group technically all belong to
the same, emptystring group.

Commit.description: Commit holds the Git-commit (SHA1) that a binary was built from, as\nreported in the version-string of external tools, such as `containerd`,\nor `runC`.

Expected.description: Commit ID of external tool expected by dockerd as set at build time.

ID.description: Actual commit ID of external tool.

ConfigReference.description: The config-only network source to provide the configuration for\nthis network.

Network.description: The name of the config-only network that provides the network's\nconfiguration. The specified network must be an existing config-only\nnetwork. Only network names are allowed, not network IDs.

ContainerConfig.description: Configuration for a container that is portable between hosts.

Cmd.description: Command to run specified as a string or an array of strings.

Domainname.description: The domain name to use for the container.

Entrypoint.description:
The entry point for the container as a string or an array of strings.

If the array consists of exactly one empty string (`[""]`) then the
entry point is reset to system default (i.e., the entry point used by
docker when there is no `ENTRYPOINT` instruction in the `Dockerfile`).

Env.description: A list of environment variables to set inside the container in the\nform `["VAR=value", ...]`. A variable without `=` is removed from the\nenvironment, rather than to have an empty value.

ExposedPorts.description: An object mapping ports to an empty object in the form:\n\n`{"<port>/<tcp|udp|sctp>": {}}`

Hostname.description: The hostname to use for the container, as a valid RFC 1123 hostname.

Image.description: The name (or reference) of the image to use when creating the container,\nor which was used when the container was created.

MacAddress.description: MAC address of the container.\n\nDeprecated: this field is deprecated in API v1.44 and up. Use EndpointSettings.MacAddress instead.

OnBuild.description: `ONBUILD` metadata that were defined in the image's `Dockerfile`.

Shell.description: Shell for when `RUN`, `CMD`, and `ENTRYPOINT` uses a shell.

StdinOnce.description: Close `stdin` after one attached client disconnects

StopSignal.description: Signal to stop a container as a string or unsigned integer.

StopTimeout.description: Timeout to stop a container in seconds.

Tty.description: Attach standard streams to a TTY, including `stdin` if it is not closed.

User.description: The user that commands are run as inside the container.

Volumes.description: An object mapping mount point paths inside the container to empty\nobjects.

WorkingDir.description: The working directory for commands to run in.

Id.description: The ID of the created container

Warnings.description: Warnings encountered when creating the container

ContainerState.description: ContainerState stores container's running state. It's part of ContainerJSONBase\nand will be returned by the "inspect" command.

ExitCode.description: The last exit code of this container

FinishedAt.description: The time when this container last exited.

OOMKilled.description: Whether a process within this container has been killed because it ran\nout of memory since the container was last started.

Pid.description: The process ID of this container

Running.description:
Whether this container is running.

Note that a running container can be _paused_. The `Running` and `Paused`
booleans are not mutually exclusive:

When pausing a container (on Linux), the freezer cgroup is used to suspend
all processes in the container. Freezing the process requires the process to
be running. As a result, paused containers are both `Running` _and_ `Paused`.

Use the `Status` field instead to determine if a container's state is "running".

StartedAt.description: The time when this container was last started.

Status.description: String representation of the container state. Can be one of "created",\n"running", "paused", "restarting", "removing", "exited", or "dead".

ContainerStatus.description: represents the status of a container.

Command.description: Command to run when starting the container

Annotations.description: Arbitrary key-value metadata attached to container

Image.description: The name of the image used when creating this container

ImageID.description: The ID of the image that this container was created from

Names.description: The names that this container has been given

NetworkSettings.description: A summary of the container's network settings

Ports.description: The ports exposed by this container

SizeRootFs.description: The total size of all the files in this container

SizeRw.description: The size of files that have been created or changed by this container

Status.description: Additional human-readable status of this container (e.g. `Exit 0`)

ContainerdInfo.description: Information for connecting to the containerd instance that is used by the daemon.\nThis is included for debugging purposes only.

Address.description: The address of the containerd socket.

Namespaces.description:
The namespaces that the daemon uses for running containers and
plugins in containerd. These namespaces can be configured in the
daemon configuration, and are considered to be used exclusively
by the daemon, Tampering with the containerd instance may cause
unexpected behavior.

As these namespaces are considered to be exclusively accessed
by the daemon, it is not recommended to change these values,
or to change them to a value that is used by other systems,
such as cri-containerd.

Containers.description:
The default containerd namespace used for containers managed
by the daemon.

The default namespace for containers is "moby", but will be
suffixed with the `<uid>.<gid>` of the remapped `root` if
user-namespaces are enabled and the containerd image-store
is used.

Plugins.description:
The default containerd namespace used for plugins managed by
the daemon.

The default namespace for plugins is "plugins.moby", but will be
suffixed with the `<uid>.<gid>` of the remapped `root` if
user-namespaces are enabled and the containerd image-store
is used.

DeviceMapping.description: A device mapping between the host and container

DeviceRequest.description: A request for devices to be sent to device drivers

Capabilities.description: A list of capabilities; an OR list of AND lists of capabilities.

Options.description: Driver-specific options, specified as a key/value pairs. These options\nare passed directly to the driver.

DistributionInspect.description: Describes the result obtained from contacting the registry to retrieve\nimage metadata.

Platforms.description: An array containing all platforms supported by the image.

DistributionInspect.title: DistributionInspectResponse

Driver.description: Driver represents a driver (network, logging, secrets).

EndpointIPAMConfig.description: EndpointIPAMConfig represents an endpoint's IPAM configuration.

PublishMode.description:
The mode in which port is published.


- "ingress" makes the target port accessible on every node, regardless of whether there is a task for the service running on that node or not. - "host" bypasses the routing mesh and publish the port directly on the swarm node where that service is running.

PublishedPort.description: The port on the swarm hosts.

DNSNames.description:
List of all DNS names an endpoint has on a specific network. This
list is based on the container name, network aliases, container short
ID, and hostname.

These DNS names are non-fully qualified but can contain several dots.
You can get fully qualified DNS names by appending `.<network-name>`.
For instance, if container name is `my.ctr` and the network is named
`testnet`, `DNSNames` will contain `my.ctr` and the FQDN will be
`my.ctr.testnet`.

DriverOpts.description: DriverOpts is a mapping of driver options and values. These options\nare passed directly to the driver and are driver specific.

EndpointID.description: Unique ID for the service endpoint in a Sandbox.

GlobalIPv6PrefixLen.description: Mask length of the global IPv6 address.

IPPrefixLen.description: Mask length of the IPv4 address.

MacAddress.description: MAC address for the endpoint on this network. The network driver might ignore this parameter.

EndpointSpec.description: Properties that can be configured to access and load balance a service.

Mode.description: The mode of resolution to use for internal load balancing between tasks.

Ports.description: List of exposed ports that this service is accessible on from the\noutside. Ports can only be provided if `vip` resolution mode is used.

EngineDescription.description: EngineDescription provides information about an engine.

EventActor.description: Actor describes something that generates events, like a container, network,\nor a volume.

Attributes.description: Various key/value attributes of the object, depending on its type.

ID.description: The ID of the object emitting the event

EventMessage.description: EventMessage represents the information an event contains.

Type.description: The type of object emitting the event

scope.description: Scope of the event. Engine events are `local` scope. Cluster (Swarm)\nevents are `swarm` scope.

timeNano.description: Timestamp of event, with nanosecond accuracy

EventMessage.title: SystemEventsResponse

Path.description: Path to file or directory that has changed.

GenericResources.description: User-defined resources can be either Integer resources (e.g, `SSD=3`) or\nString resources (e.g, `GPU=UUID1`).

GraphDriverData.description: Information about the storage driver used to store the container's and\nimage's filesystem.

Data.description:
Low-level storage metadata, provided as key/value pairs.

This information is driver-specific, and depends on the storage-driver
in use, and should be used for informational purposes only.

Health.description: Health stores information about the container's healthcheck results.

FailingStreak.description: FailingStreak is the number of consecutive failures

Log.description: Log contains the last few results (oldest first)

Status.description:
Status is one of `none`, `starting`, `healthy` or `unhealthy`

- "none"      Indicates there is no healthcheck
- "starting"  Starting indicates that the container is not yet ready
- "healthy"   Healthy indicates that the container is running correctly
- "unhealthy" Unhealthy indicates that the container has a problem

HealthConfig.description: A test to perform to check that the container is healthy.

Interval.description: The time to wait between checks in nanoseconds. It should be 0 or at\nleast 1000000 (1 ms). 0 means inherit.

Retries.description: The number of consecutive failures needed to consider a container as\nunhealthy. 0 means inherit.

StartInterval.description: The time to wait between checks in nanoseconds during the start period.\nIt should be 0 or at least 1000000 (1 ms). 0 means inherit.

StartPeriod.description: Start period for the container to initialize before starting\nhealth-retries countdown in nanoseconds. It should be 0 or at least\n1000000 (1 ms). 0 means inherit.

Test.description:
The test to perform. Possible values are:

- `[]` inherit healthcheck from image or parent image
- `["NONE"]` disable healthcheck
- `["CMD", args...]` exec arguments directly
- `["CMD-SHELL", command]` run command with system's default shell

Timeout.description: The time to wait before considering the check to have hung. It should\nbe 0 or at least 1000000 (1 ms). 0 means inherit.

HealthcheckResult.description: HealthcheckResult stores information about a single run of a healthcheck probe

End.description: Date and time at which this check ended in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

ExitCode.description:
ExitCode meanings:

- `0` healthy
- `1` unhealthy
- `2` reserved (considered unhealthy)
- other values: error running probe

Start.description: Date and time at which this check started in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

Annotations.description: Arbitrary non-identifying metadata attached to container and\nprovided to the runtime when the container is started.

AutoRemove.description: Automatically remove the container when the container's process\nexits. This has no effect if `RestartPolicy` is set.

Binds.description:
A list of volume bindings for this container. Each volume binding
is a string in one of these forms:

- `host-src:container-dest[:options]` to bind-mount a host path
  into the container. Both `host-src`, and `container-dest` must
  be an _absolute_ path.
- `volume-name:container-dest[:options]` to bind-mount a volume
  managed by a volume driver into the container. `container-dest`
  must be an _absolute_ path.

`options` is an optional, comma-delimited list of:

- `nocopy` disables automatic copying of data from the container
  path to the volume. The `nocopy` flag only applies to named volumes.
- `[ro|rw]` mounts a volume read-only or read-write, respectively.
  If omitted or set to `rw`, volumes are mounted read-write.
- `[z|Z]` applies SELinux labels to allow or deny multiple containers
  to read and write to the same volume.
    - `z`: a _shared_ content label is applied to the content. This
      label indicates that multiple containers can share the volume
      content, for both reading and writing.
    - `Z`: a _private unshared_ label is applied to the content.
      This label indicates that only the current container can use
      a private volume. Labeling systems such as SELinux require
      proper labels to be placed on volume content that is mounted
      into a container. Without a label, the security system can
      prevent a container's processes from using the content. By
      default, the labels set by the host operating system are not
      modified.
- `[[r]shared|[r]slave|[r]private]` specifies mount
  [propagation behavior](https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/filesystems/sharedsubtree.txt).
  This only applies to bind-mounted volumes, not internal volumes
  or named volumes. Mount propagation requires the source mount
  point (the location where the source directory is mounted in the
  host operating system) to have the correct propagation properties.
  For shared volumes, the source mount point must be set to `shared`.
  For slave volumes, the mount must be set to either `shared` or
  `slave`.

CapAdd.description: A list of kernel capabilities to add to the container. Conflicts\nwith option 'Capabilities'.

CapDrop.description: A list of kernel capabilities to drop from the container. Conflicts\nwith option 'Capabilities'.

Cgroup.description: Cgroup to use for the container.

CgroupnsMode.description:
cgroup namespace mode for the container. Possible values are:

- `"private"`: the container runs in its own private cgroup namespace
- `"host"`: use the host system's cgroup namespace

If not specified, the daemon default is used, which can either be `"private"`
or `"host"`, depending on daemon version, kernel support and configuration.

ConsoleSize.description: Initial console size, as an `[height, width]` array.

ContainerIDFile.description: Path to a file where the container ID is written

Dns.description: A list of DNS servers for the container to use.

DnsSearch.description: A list of DNS search domains.

ExtraHosts.description: A list of hostnames/IP mappings to add to the container's `/etc/hosts`\nfile. Specified in the form `["hostname:IP"]`.

GroupAdd.description: A list of additional groups that the container process will run as.

IpcMode.description:
IPC sharing mode for the container. Possible values are:

- `"none"`: own private IPC namespace, with /dev/shm not mounted
- `"private"`: own private IPC namespace
- `"shareable"`: own private IPC namespace, with a possibility to share it with other containers
- `"container:<name|id>"`: join another (shareable) container's IPC namespace
- `"host"`: use the host system's IPC namespace

If not specified, daemon default is used, which can either be `"private"`
or `"shareable"`, depending on daemon version and configuration.

Isolation.description: Isolation technology of the container. (Windows only)

Links.description: A list of links for the container in the form `container_name:alias`.

LogConfig.description: The logging configuration for this container

MaskedPaths.description: The list of paths to be masked inside the container (this overrides\nthe default set of paths).

Mounts.description: Specification for mounts to be added to the container.

NetworkMode.description:
Network mode to use for this container. Supported standard values
are: `bridge`, `host`, `none`, and `container:<name|id>`. Any
other value is taken as a custom network's name to which this
container should connect to.

OomScoreAdj.description: An integer value containing the score given to the container in\norder to tune OOM killer preferences.

PidMode.description:
Set the PID (Process) Namespace mode for the container. It can be
either:

- `"container:<name|id>"`: joins another container's PID namespace
- `"host"`: use the host's PID namespace inside the container

Privileged.description: Gives the container full access to the host.

PublishAllPorts.description:
Allocates an ephemeral host port for all of a container's
exposed ports.

Ports are de-allocated when the container stops and allocated when
the container starts. The allocated port might be changed when
restarting the container.

The port is selected from the ephemeral port range that depends on
the kernel. For example, on Linux the range is defined by
`/proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_local_port_range`.

ReadonlyPaths.description: The list of paths to be set as read-only inside the container\n(this overrides the default set of paths).

ReadonlyRootfs.description: Mount the container's root filesystem as read only.

Runtime.description: Runtime to use with this container.

SecurityOpt.description: A list of string values to customize labels for MLS systems, such\nas SELinux.

ShmSize.description: Size of `/dev/shm` in bytes. If omitted, the system uses 64MB.

StorageOpt.description: Storage driver options for this container, in the form `{"size": "120G"}`.

Sysctls.description:
A list of kernel parameters (sysctls) to set in the container.
For example:

```
{"net.ipv4.ip_forward": "1"}
```

Tmpfs.description:
A map of container directories which should be replaced by tmpfs
mounts, and their corresponding mount options. For example:

```
{ "/run": "rw,noexec,nosuid,size=65536k" }
```

UTSMode.description: UTS namespace to use for the container.

UsernsMode.description: Sets the usernamespace mode for the container when usernamespace\nremapping option is enabled.

VolumeDriver.description: Driver that this container uses to mount volumes.

VolumesFrom.description: A list of volumes to inherit from another container, specified in\nthe form `<container name>[:<ro|rw>]`.

HostConfig.description: Container configuration that depends on the host we are running on

Config.description:
List of IPAM configuration options, specified as a map:

```
{"Subnet": <CIDR>, "IPRange": <CIDR>, "Gateway": <IP address>, "AuxAddress": <device_name:IP address>}
```

Driver.description: Name of the IPAM driver to use.

Options.description: Driver-specific options, specified as a map.

IdResponse.description: Response to an API call that returns just an Id

Id.description: The id of the newly created object.

ImageConfig.description: Configuration of the image. These fields are used as defaults\nwhen starting a container from the image.

example.Healthcheck: map[Interval:0 Retries:0 StartInterval:0 StartPeriod:0 Test:[string] Timeout:0]

AttachStderr.description:
Whether to attach to `stderr`.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always false. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

AttachStdin.description:
Whether to attach to `stdin`.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always false. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

AttachStdout.description:
Whether to attach to `stdout`.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always false. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

Cmd.description: Command to run specified as a string or an array of strings.

Domainname.description:
The domain name to use for the container.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always empty. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

Entrypoint.description:
The entry point for the container as a string or an array of strings.

If the array consists of exactly one empty string (`[""]`) then the
entry point is reset to system default (i.e., the entry point used by
docker when there is no `ENTRYPOINT` instruction in the `Dockerfile`).

Env.description: A list of environment variables to set inside the container in the\nform `["VAR=value", ...]`. A variable without `=` is removed from the\nenvironment, rather than to have an empty value.

ExposedPorts.description: An object mapping ports to an empty object in the form:\n\n`{"<port>/<tcp|udp|sctp>": {}}`

Hostname.description:
The hostname to use for the container, as a valid RFC 1123 hostname.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always empty. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

Image.description:
The name (or reference) of the image to use when creating the container, or which was used when the container was created.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always empty. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

MacAddress.description:
MAC address of the container.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always omitted. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

NetworkDisabled.description:
Disable networking for the container.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always omitted. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

OnBuild.description: `ONBUILD` metadata that were defined in the image's `Dockerfile`.

OpenStdin.description:
Open `stdin`


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always false. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

Shell.description: Shell for when `RUN`, `CMD`, and `ENTRYPOINT` uses a shell.

StdinOnce.description:
Close `stdin` after one attached client disconnects.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always false. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

StopSignal.description: Signal to stop a container as a string or unsigned integer.

StopTimeout.description:
Timeout to stop a container in seconds.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always omitted. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

Tty.description:
Attach standard streams to a TTY, including `stdin` if it is not closed.


> **Deprecated**: this field is not part of the image specification and is > always false. It must not be used, and will be removed in API v1.47.

User.description: The user that commands are run as inside the container.

Volumes.description: An object mapping mount point paths inside the container to empty\nobjects.

WorkingDir.description: The working directory for commands to run in.

Deleted.description: The image ID of an image that was deleted

Untagged.description: The image ID of an image that was untagged

ImageInspect.description: Information about an image in the local image cache.

Architecture.description: Hardware CPU architecture that the image runs on.

Author.description: Name of the author that was specified when committing the image, or as\nspecified through MAINTAINER (deprecated) in the Dockerfile.

Comment.description: Optional message that was set when committing or importing the image.

Created.description:
Date and time at which the image was created, formatted in
[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

This information is only available if present in the image,
and omitted otherwise.

DockerVersion.description: The version of Docker that was used to build the image.\n\nDepending on how the image was created, this field may be empty.

Id.description:
ID is the content-addressable ID of an image.

This identifier is a content-addressable digest calculated from the
image's configuration (which includes the digests of layers used by
the image).

Note that this digest differs from the `RepoDigests` below, which
holds digests of image manifests that reference the image.

Metadata.description: Additional metadata of the image in the local cache. This information\nis local to the daemon, and not part of the image itself.

LastTagTime.description:
Date and time at which the image was last tagged in
[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

This information is only available if the image was tagged locally,
and omitted otherwise.

Os.description: Operating System the image is built to run on.

OsVersion.description: Operating System version the image is built to run on (especially\nfor Windows).

Parent.description:
ID of the parent image.

Depending on how the image was created, this field may be empty and
is only set for images that were built/created locally. This field
is empty if the image was pulled from an image registry.

RepoDigests.description:
List of content-addressable digests of locally available image manifests
that the image is referenced from. Multiple manifests can refer to the
same image.

These digests are usually only available if the image was either pulled
from a registry, or if the image was pushed to a registry, which is when
the manifest is generated and its digest calculated.

RepoTags.description:
List of image names/tags in the local image cache that reference this
image.

Multiple image tags can refer to the same image, and this list may be
empty if no tags reference the image, in which case the image is
"untagged", in which case it can still be referenced by its ID.

RootFS.description: Information about the image's RootFS, including the layer IDs.

Size.description: Total size of the image including all layers it is composed of.

VirtualSize.description: Total size of the image including all layers it is composed of.\n\nDeprecated: this field is omitted in API v1.44, but kept for backward compatibility. Use Size instead.

Containers.description:
Number of containers using this image. Includes both stopped and running
containers.

This size is not calculated by default, and depends on which API endpoint
is used. `-1` indicates that the value has not been set / calculated.

Created.description: Date and time at which the image was created as a Unix timestamp\n(number of seconds sinds EPOCH).

Id.description:
ID is the content-addressable ID of an image.

This identifier is a content-addressable digest calculated from the
image's configuration (which includes the digests of layers used by
the image).

Note that this digest differs from the `RepoDigests` below, which
holds digests of image manifests that reference the image.

ParentId.description:
ID of the parent image.

Depending on how the image was created, this field may be empty and
is only set for images that were built/created locally. This field
is empty if the image was pulled from an image registry.

RepoDigests.description:
List of content-addressable digests of locally available image manifests
that the image is referenced from. Multiple manifests can refer to the
same image.

These digests are usually only available if the image was either pulled
from a registry, or if the image was pushed to a registry, which is when
the manifest is generated and its digest calculated.

RepoTags.description:
List of image names/tags in the local image cache that reference this
image.

Multiple image tags can refer to the same image, and this list may be
empty if no tags reference the image, in which case the image is
"untagged", in which case it can still be referenced by its ID.

SharedSize.description:
Total size of image layers that are shared between this image and other
images.

This size is not calculated by default. `-1` indicates that the value
has not been set / calculated.

Size.description: Total size of the image including all layers it is composed of.

VirtualSize.description: Total size of the image including all layers it is composed of.\n\nDeprecated: this field is omitted in API v1.44, but kept for backward compatibility. Use Size instead.

IndexInfo.description: IndexInfo contains information about a registry.

Mirrors.description: List of mirrors, expressed as URIs.

Name.description: Name of the registry, such as "docker.io".

Official.description: Indicates whether this is an official registry (i.e., Docker Hub / docker.io)

Secure.description:
Indicates if the registry is part of the list of insecure
registries.

If `false`, the registry is insecure. Insecure registries accept
un-encrypted (HTTP) and/or untrusted (HTTPS with certificates from
unknown CAs) communication.

> **Warning**: Insecure registries can be useful when running a local
> registry. However, because its use creates security vulnerabilities
> it should ONLY be enabled for testing purposes. For increased
> security, users should add their CA to their system's list of
> trusted CAs instead of enabling this option.

JoinTokens.description: JoinTokens contains the tokens workers and managers need to join the swarm.

Manager.description: The token managers can use to join the swarm.

Worker.description: The token workers can use to join the swarm.

Limit.description: An object describing a limit on resources which can be requested by a task.

Pids.description: Limits the maximum number of PIDs in the container. Set `0` for unlimited.

LocalNodeState.description: Current local status of this node.

ManagerStatus.description:
ManagerStatus represents the status of a manager.

It provides the current status of a node's manager component, if the node
is a manager.

Addr.description: The IP address and port at which the manager is reachable.

CreateMountpoint.description: Create mount point on host if missing

Propagation.description: A propagation mode with the value `[r]private`, `[r]shared`, or `[r]slave`.

ReadOnlyForceRecursive.description: Raise an error if the mount cannot be made recursively read-only.

ReadOnlyNonRecursive.description:
Make the mount non-recursively read-only, but still leave the mount recursive
(unless NonRecursive is set to `true` in conjunction).

Addded in v1.44, before that version all read-only mounts were
non-recursive by default. To match the previous behaviour this
will default to `true` for clients on versions prior to v1.44.

Consistency.description: The consistency requirement for the mount: `default`, `consistent`, `cached`, or `delegated`.

ReadOnly.description: Whether the mount should be read-only.

Source.description: Mount source (e.g. a volume name, a host path).

Mode.description: The permission mode for the tmpfs mount in an integer.

Options.description:
The options to be passed to the tmpfs mount. An array of arrays.
Flag options should be provided as 1-length arrays. Other types
should be provided as as 2-length arrays, where the first item is
the key and the second the value.

SizeBytes.description: The size for the tmpfs mount in bytes.

Type.description:
The mount type. Available types:

- `bind` Mounts a file or directory from the host into the container. Must exist prior to creating the container.
- `volume` Creates a volume with the given name and options (or uses a pre-existing volume with the same name and options). These are **not** removed when the container is removed.
- `tmpfs` Create a tmpfs with the given options. The mount source cannot be specified for tmpfs.
- `npipe` Mounts a named pipe from the host into the container. Must exist prior to creating the container.
- `cluster` a Swarm cluster volume

Name.description: Name of the driver to use to create the volume.

Options.description: key/value map of driver specific options.

NoCopy.description: Populate volume with data from the target.

Subpath.description: Source path inside the volume. Must be relative without any back traversals.

MountPoint.description: MountPoint represents a mount point configuration inside the container.\nThis is used for reporting the mountpoints in use by a container.

Destination.description: Destination is the path relative to the container root (`/`) where\nthe `Source` is mounted inside the container.

Driver.description: Driver is the volume driver used to create the volume (if it is a volume).

Mode.description:
Mode is a comma separated list of options supplied by the user when
creating the bind/volume mount.

The default is platform-specific (`"z"` on Linux, empty on Windows).

Name.description: Name is the name reference to the underlying data defined by `Source`\ne.g., the volume name.

Propagation.description: Propagation describes how mounts are propagated from the host into the\nmount point, and vice-versa. Refer to the [Linux kernel documentation](https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/filesystems/sharedsubtree.txt)\nfor details. This field is not used on Windows.

RW.description: Whether the mount is mounted writable (read-write).

Source.description:
Source location of the mount.

For volumes, this contains the storage location of the volume (within
`/var/lib/docker/volumes/`). For bind-mounts, and `npipe`, this contains
the source (host) part of the bind-mount. For `tmpfs` mount points, this
field is empty.

Type.description:
The mount type:

- `bind` a mount of a file or directory from the host into the container.
- `volume` a docker volume with the given `Name`.
- `tmpfs` a `tmpfs`.
- `npipe` a named pipe from the host into the container.
- `cluster` a Swarm cluster volume

Attachable.description: Wheter a global / swarm scope network is manually attachable by regular\ncontainers from workers in swarm mode.

ConfigOnly.description:
Whether the network is a config-only network. Config-only networks are
placeholder networks for network configurations to be used by other
networks. Config-only networks cannot be used directly to run containers
or services.

Containers.description: Contains endpoints attached to the network.

Created.description: Date and time at which the network was created in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

Driver.description: The name of the driver used to create the network (e.g. `bridge`,\n`overlay`).

EnableIPv6.description: Whether the network was created with IPv6 enabled.

Id.description: ID that uniquely identifies a network on a single machine.

Ingress.description: Whether the network is providing the routing-mesh for the swarm cluster.

Internal.description: Whether the network is created to only allow internal networking\nconnectivity.

Options.description: Network-specific options uses when creating the network.

Peers.description: List of peer nodes for an overlay network. This field is only present\nfor overlay networks, and omitted for other network types.

Scope.description: The level at which the network exists (e.g. `swarm` for cluster-wide\nor `local` for machine level)

NetworkAttachmentConfig.description: Specifies how a service should be attached to a particular network.

Aliases.description: Discoverable alternate names for the service on this network.

DriverOpts.description: Driver attachment options for the network target.

Target.description: The target network for attachment. Must be a network name or ID.

Id.description: The ID of the created network.

Warning.description: Warnings encountered when creating the container

NetworkSettings.description: NetworkSettings exposes the network settings in the API

Bridge.description: Name of the default bridge interface when dockerd's --bridge flag is set.

EndpointID.description:
EndpointID uniquely represents a service endpoint in a Sandbox.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

Gateway.description:
Gateway address for the default "bridge" network.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

GlobalIPv6Address.description:
Global IPv6 address for the default "bridge" network.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

GlobalIPv6PrefixLen.description:
Mask length of the global IPv6 address.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

HairpinMode.description: Indicates if hairpin NAT should be enabled on the virtual interface.\n\nDeprecated: This field is never set and will be removed in a future release.

IPAddress.description:
IPv4 address for the default "bridge" network.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

IPPrefixLen.description:
Mask length of the IPv4 address.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

IPv6Gateway.description:
IPv6 gateway address for this network.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

LinkLocalIPv6Address.description: IPv6 unicast address using the link-local prefix.\n\nDeprecated: This field is never set and will be removed in a future release.

LinkLocalIPv6PrefixLen.description: Prefix length of the IPv6 unicast address.\n\nDeprecated: This field is never set and will be removed in a future release.

MacAddress.description:
MAC address for the container on the default "bridge" network.


> **Deprecated**: This field is only propagated when attached to the > default "bridge" network. Use the information from the "bridge" > network inside the `Networks` map instead, which contains the same > information. This field was deprecated in Docker 1.9 and is scheduled > to be removed in Docker 17.12.0

Networks.description: Information about all networks that the container is connected to.

SandboxID.description: SandboxID uniquely represents a container's network stack.

SandboxKey.description: SandboxKey is the full path of the netns handle

SecondaryIPAddresses.description: Deprecated: This field is never set and will be removed in a future release.

SecondaryIPv6Addresses.description: Deprecated: This field is never set and will be removed in a future release.

NetworkingConfig.description:
NetworkingConfig represents the container's networking configuration for
each of its interfaces.
It is used for the networking configs specified in the `docker create`
and `docker network connect` commands.

example.EndpointsConfig: map[database_nw:map[] isolated_nw:map[Aliases:[server_x server_y] IPAMConfig:map[IPv4Address:172.20.30.33 IPv6Address:2001:db8:abcd::3033 LinkLocalIPs:[169.254.34.68 fe80::3468]] Links:[container_1 container_2] MacAddress:02:42:ac:12:05:02]]

EndpointsConfig.description: A mapping of network name to endpoint configuration for that network.\nThe endpoint configuration can be left empty to connect to that\nnetwork with no particular endpoint configuration.

CreatedAt.description: Date and time at which the node was added to the swarm in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

UpdatedAt.description: Date and time at which the node was last updated in\n[RFC 3339](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt) format with nano-seconds.

NodeDescription.description: NodeDescription encapsulates the properties of the Node as reported by the\nagent.

NodeState.description: NodeState represents the state of a node.

NodeStatus.description: NodeStatus represents the status of a node.\n\nIt provides the current status of the node, as seen by the manager.

OCIDescriptor.description: A descriptor struct containing digest, media type, and size, as defined in\nthe [OCI Content Descriptors Specification](https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec/blob/v1.0.1/descriptor.md).

digest.description: The digest of the targeted content.

mediaType.description: The media type of the object this schema refers to.

size.description: The size in bytes of the blob.

OCIPlatform.description: Describes the platform which the image in the manifest runs on, as defined\nin the [OCI Image Index Specification](https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec/blob/v1.0.1/image-index.md).

architecture.description: The CPU architecture, for example `amd64` or `ppc64`.

os.description: The operating system, for example `linux` or `windows`.

os_DOT_features.description: Optional field specifying an array of strings, each listing a required\nOS feature (for example on Windows `win32k`).

os_DOT_version.description: Optional field specifying the operating system version, for example on\nWindows `10.0.19041.1165`.

variant.description: Optional field specifying a variant of the CPU, for example `v7` to\nspecify ARMv7 when architecture is `arm`.

ObjectVersion.description:
The version number of the object such as node, service, etc. This is needed
to avoid conflicting writes. The client must send the version number along
with the modified specification when updating these objects.

This approach ensures safe concurrency and determinism in that the change
on the object may not be applied if the version number has changed from the
last read. In other words, if two update requests specify the same base
version, only one of the requests can succeed. As a result, two separate
update requests that happen at the same time will not unintentionally
overwrite each other.

PeerInfo.description: PeerInfo represents one peer of an overlay network.

IP.description: IP-address of the peer-node in the Swarm cluster.

Name.description: ID of the peer-node in the Swarm cluster.

PeerNode.description: Represents a peer-node in the swarm

Addr.description: IP address and ports at which this node can be reached.

NodeID.description: Unique identifier of for this node in the swarm.

Architecture.description: Architecture represents the hardware architecture (for example,\n`x86_64`).

OS.description: OS represents the Operating System (for example, `linux` or `windows`).

Plugin.description: A plugin for the Engine API

Description.example: A sample volume plugin for Docker

DockerVersion.description: Docker Version used to create the plugin

example: map[Description:If set, prints debug messages Name:DEBUG Value:0]

Interface.description: The interface between Docker and the plugin

ProtocolScheme.description: Protocol to use for clients connecting to the plugin.

Enabled.description: True if the plugin is running. False if the plugin is not running, only installed.

PluginReference.description: plugin remote reference used to push/pull the plugin

Settings.description: Settings that can be modified by users.

Description.example: This is a mount that's used by the plugin.

PluginPrivilege.description: Describes a permission the user has to accept upon installing\nthe plugin.

PluginsInfo.description:
Available plugins per type.


> **Note**: Only unmanaged (V1) plugins are included in this list. > V1 plugins are "lazily" loaded, and are not returned in this list > if there is no resource using the plugin.

Log.description: Names of available logging-drivers, and logging-driver plugins.

Network.description: Names of available network-drivers, and network-driver plugins.

Volume.description: Names of available volume-drivers, and network-driver plugins.

Port.description: An open port on a container

IP.description: Host IP address that the container's port is mapped to

PortBinding.description: PortBinding represents a binding between a host IP address and a host\nport.

HostIp.description: Host IP address that the container's port is mapped to.

HostPort.description: Host port number that the container's port is mapped to.

PortMap.description:
PortMap describes the mapping of container ports to host ports, using the
container's port-number and protocol as key in the format `<port>/<protocol>`,
for example, `80/udp`.

If a container's port is mapped for multiple protocols, separate entries
are added to the mapping table.

PortStatus.description: represents the port status of a task's host ports whose service has published host ports

Reachability.description: Reachability represents the reachability of a node.

RegistryServiceConfig.description: RegistryServiceConfig stores daemon registry services configuration.

AllowNondistributableArtifactsCIDRs.description:
List of IP ranges to which nondistributable artifacts can be pushed,
using the CIDR syntax [RFC 4632](https://tools.ietf.org/html/4632).

Some images (for example, Windows base images) contain artifacts
whose distribution is restricted by license. When these images are
pushed to a registry, restricted artifacts are not included.

This configuration override this behavior, and enables the daemon to
push nondistributable artifacts to all registries whose resolved IP
address is within the subnet described by the CIDR syntax.

This option is useful when pushing images containing
nondistributable artifacts to a registry on an air-gapped network so
hosts on that network can pull the images without connecting to
another server.

> **Warning**: Nondistributable artifacts typically have restrictions
> on how and where they can be distributed and shared. Only use this
> feature to push artifacts to private registries and ensure that you
> are in compliance with any terms that cover redistributing
> nondistributable artifacts.

AllowNondistributableArtifactsHostnames.description:
List of registry hostnames to which nondistributable artifacts can be
pushed, using the format `<hostname>[:<port>]` or `<IP address>[:<port>]`.

Some images (for example, Windows base images) contain artifacts
whose distribution is restricted by license. When these images are
pushed to a registry, restricted artifacts are not included.

This configuration override this behavior for the specified
registries.

This option is useful when pushing images containing
nondistributable artifacts to a registry on an air-gapped network so
hosts on that network can pull the images without connecting to
another server.

> **Warning**: Nondistributable artifacts typically have restrictions
> on how and where they can be distributed and shared. Only use this
> feature to push artifacts to private registries and ensure that you
> are in compliance with any terms that cover redistributing
> nondistributable artifacts.

InsecureRegistryCIDRs.description:
List of IP ranges of insecure registries, using the CIDR syntax
([RFC 4632](https://tools.ietf.org/html/4632)). Insecure registries
accept un-encrypted (HTTP) and/or untrusted (HTTPS with certificates
from unknown CAs) communication.

By default, local registries (`127.0.0.0/8`) are configured as
insecure. All other registries are secure. Communicating with an
insecure registry is not possible if the daemon assumes that registry
is secure.

This configuration override this behavior, insecure communication with
registries whose resolved IP address is within the subnet described by
the CIDR syntax.

Registries can also be marked insecure by hostname. Those registries
are listed under `IndexConfigs` and have their `Secure` field set to
`false`.

> **Warning**: Using this option can be useful when running a local
> registry, but introduces security vulnerabilities. This option
> should therefore ONLY be used for testing purposes. For increased
> security, users should add their CA to their system's list of trusted
> CAs instead of enabling this option.

Mirrors.description: List of registry URLs that act as a mirror for the official\n(`docker.io`) registry.

ResourceObject.description: An object describing the resources which can be advertised by a node and\nrequested by a task.

Resources.description: A container's resources (cgroups config, ulimits, etc)

BlkioDeviceReadBps.description:
Limit read rate (bytes per second) from a device, in the form:

```
[{"Path": "device_path", "Rate": rate}]
```

BlkioDeviceReadIOps.description:
Limit read rate (IO per second) from a device, in the form:

```
[{"Path": "device_path", "Rate": rate}]
```

BlkioDeviceWriteBps.description:
Limit write rate (bytes per second) to a device, in the form:

```
[{"Path": "device_path", "Rate": rate}]
```

BlkioDeviceWriteIOps.description:
Limit write rate (IO per second) to a device, in the form:

```
[{"Path": "device_path", "Rate": rate}]
```

BlkioWeightDevice.description:
Block IO weight (relative device weight) in the form:

```
[{"Path": "device_path", "Weight": weight}]
```

CgroupParent.description:
Path to `cgroups` under which the container's `cgroup` is created. If
the path is not absolute, the path is considered to be relative to the
`cgroups` path of the init process. Cgroups are created if they do not
already exist.

CpuCount.description:
The number of usable CPUs (Windows only).

On Windows Server containers, the processor resource controls are
mutually exclusive. The order of precedence is `CPUCount` first, then
`CPUShares`, and `CPUPercent` last.

CpuPercent.description:
The usable percentage of the available CPUs (Windows only).

On Windows Server containers, the processor resource controls are
mutually exclusive. The order of precedence is `CPUCount` first, then
`CPUShares`, and `CPUPercent` last.

CpuPeriod.description: The length of a CPU period in microseconds.

CpuQuota.description: Microseconds of CPU time that the container can get in a CPU period.

CpuRealtimePeriod.description: The length of a CPU real-time period in microseconds. Set to 0 to\nallocate no time allocated to real-time tasks.

CpuRealtimeRuntime.description: The length of a CPU real-time runtime in microseconds. Set to 0 to\nallocate no time allocated to real-time tasks.

CpuShares.description: An integer value representing this container's relative CPU weight\nversus other containers.

CpusetCpus.description: CPUs in which to allow execution (e.g., `0-3`, `0,1`).

CpusetMems.description: Memory nodes (MEMs) in which to allow execution (0-3, 0,1). Only\neffective on NUMA systems.

DeviceCgroupRules.description: a list of cgroup rules to apply to the container

DeviceRequests.description: A list of requests for devices to be sent to device drivers.

Devices.description: A list of devices to add to the container.

IOMaximumBandwidth.description: Maximum IO in bytes per second for the container system drive\n(Windows only).

IOMaximumIOps.description: Maximum IOps for the container system drive (Windows only)

Init.description: Run an init inside the container that forwards signals and reaps\nprocesses. This field is omitted if empty, and the default (as\nconfigured on the daemon) is used.

KernelMemoryTCP.description:
Hard limit for kernel TCP buffer memory (in bytes). Depending on the
OCI runtime in use, this option may be ignored. It is no longer supported
by the default (runc) runtime.

This field is omitted when empty.

MemorySwap.description: Total memory limit (memory + swap). Set as `-1` to enable unlimited\nswap.

MemorySwappiness.description: Tune a container's memory swappiness behavior. Accepts an integer\nbetween 0 and 100.

NanoCpus.description: CPU quota in units of 10<sup>-9</sup> CPUs.

OomKillDisable.description: Disable OOM Killer for the container.

PidsLimit.description: Tune a container's PIDs limit. Set `0` or `-1` for unlimited, or `null`\nto not change.

Ulimits.description:
A list of resource limits to set in the container. For example:

```
{"Name": "nofile", "Soft": 1024, "Hard": 2048}
```

RestartPolicy.description:
The behavior to apply when the container exits. The default is not to
restart.

An ever increasing delay (double the previous delay, starting at 100ms) is
added before each restart to prevent flooding the server.

MaximumRetryCount.description: If `on-failure` is used, the number of times to retry before giving up.

Name.description:
- Empty string means not to restart
- `no` Do not automatically restart
- `always` Always restart
- `unless-stopped` Restart always except when the user has manually stopped the container
- `on-failure` Restart only when the container exit code is non-zero

Runtime.description:
Runtime describes an [OCI compliant](https://github.com/opencontainers/runtime-spec)
runtime.

The runtime is invoked by the daemon via the `containerd` daemon. OCI
runtimes act as an interface to the Linux kernel namespaces, cgroups,
and SELinux.

path.description:
Name and, optional, path, of the OCI executable binary.

If the path is omitted, the daemon searches the host's `$PATH` for the
binary and uses the first result.

runtimeArgs.description: List of command-line arguments to pass to the runtime when invoked.

status.description:
Information specific to the runtime. While this API specification does not define data provided by runtimes, the following well-known properties may be provided by runtimes: `org.opencontainers.runtime-spec.features`: features structure as defined in the [OCI Runtime Specification](https://github.com/opencontainers/runtime-spec/blob/main/features.md), in a JSON string representation.


> **Note**: The information returned in this field, including the > formatting of values and labels, should not be considered stable, > and may change without notice.

Data.description:
Base64-url-safe-encoded ([RFC 4648](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-5))
data to store as secret.

This field is only used to _create_ a secret, and is not returned by
other endpoints.
